be paid by an applicant or appellant part 2005   9272011   purpose this chapter creates an administrative hearing and adjudicatory system to act upon quasijudicial and other administrative matters to a review certain land use and regulatory matters  and b ensure due process and appearance of fairness in such proceedings  9272011   10282014   creation of hearing examiner the position of the city of cheney hearing examiner is created the hearing examiner is referred to as the hearing examiner or examiner part 2005   9272011   10282014   appointment of an examiner the hearing examiner shall be appointed by the mayor and approved by the city council the terms of the appointment may be made professional service contract or intergovernmental agreement part 2005   9272011   10282014   qualifications the hearing examiners shall be licensed to practice law in the state of washington and possess qualifications related to the duties of the office to include training and experience to conduct administrative or quasijudicial hearings with expertise in administrative law land use law and planning and the ability to conduct public hearings and issue decisions part 2005   9272011   10282014   freedom from improper influence no person including city officials elective or appointive shall attempt to influence an examiner in any pending matter except at a public hearing duly called for such purposes or to interfere with any examiner in the performance of his duties in any other way  provided that this section shall not prohibit the city attorney from rendering legal services to the examiner upon request or prohibit other persons or officials from responding in writing to requests for information from the examiner  9272011   duties and powers a the examiner shall exercise the authority designated in title 10 environment title 21 zoning title 22 subdivisions and chapter  appeals of the cheney municipal such other matters which may be assigned to the hearing examiner from time to time by action of the city council hearings held by the hearing examiner shall constitute the hearings required by state law or city ordinance the hearing examiners decision shall have the effect of either a recommendation or an administrative decision appealable within a specified time to the city council in writing by an aggrieved party the hearing examiner shall hear the following matters 1 binding site plans five lots or more  2 conditional use permits  3 critical areas reviews  4 variances  5 appeals from a planning official decision including but not limited to binding site plan four lots or less short plat lot line adjustmentmerger permit review decisions administrative interpretations  6 appeals of the public works directors decisions under chapter 1908  and 7 appeals of sepa threshold determinations b the examiners decision shall be in writing and include findings and conclusions based upon the record the findings and conclusions shall to the extent applicable set forth the manner in which the decision would carry out and conform to state law the city comprehensive plan development regulations policies rules or standards of the city  1222019   10282014   9272011  part 2005   planning staff report on any matter coming before the hearing examiner the responsible city department shall coordinate and assemble relevant information and documents from city departments governmental agencies and other interested parties to include a staff report summarizing the facts and depending on the matter findings and recommendations at least five calendar days prior to the scheduled hearing the staff report will be filed with the examiner and copies mailed to the applicant and made available for public inspection  10282014   9272011   rules the following procedures shall be followed by the hearing examiner provided that the hearing examiner is granted the authority to prescribe such other rules and procedural matters as necessary to conduct a fair and timely hearing a the hearing examiner shall ensure that 1 reasonable notice is given to the applicant and all interested parties of the dates for the hearing  2 the hearing is conducted in general conformance with rcw  as modified in the reasonable discretion of the hearing examiner  and 3 cause a record of the proceedings to be maintained which shall constitute the basis for the decision or recommendation b the hearing examiner shall issue a written decision including findings of fact and conclusions based upon the record within ten calendar days following the conclusion of the hearing and submission of all written materials unless otherwise provided by law c a copy of the hearing examiners written decision or recommendation shall be transmitted by mail to the applicant and other parties of record and filed with the city clerk d the applicant and any person with legal standing may request reconsideration of the decision of the hearing examiner based an erroneous interpretation of law an unlawful procedure an erroneous application of law to fact or a failure to make a decision based upon substantial evidence the written request for reconsideration shall be submitted to the city clerk within ten days of the date of the decision the request shall set forth the specific errors or new information which should be considered by the hearing examiner thereafter the examiner may make such orders and decision as reasonably necessary e all decisions shall be shall be open to public inspection  10282014   9272011  part 2005   enforcement hearings a the hearing examiner may hear appeals of code enforcement violations in addition to the municipal court system using the same process as described in section  b notice to the appellant shall be processed as described in title 127 civil infraction system c appeal to the superior court of the hearing examiners decision in an enforcement hearing shall be filed within 21 calendar days of the examiners written decision  10282014   9272011 type of hearing and appeal procedure the examiner will conduct either an open record hearing or a closed record appeal as defined in rcw 3670b020 as amended for the purpose of an enforcement hearing there shall be an open record hearing which shall follow issuance of the code enforcement violation city ordinance or state law shall prescribe whether the examiner is conducting an open record or closed record proceeding for an open record hearing the appellant the applicant and the city as appropriate shall be designated parties to the proceeding each party may participate and present testimony or written documents the hearing examiner may allow testimony and the submission of information by interested persons groups associations or other entities where the hearing examiner is conducting an appeal proceeding participation by interested persons groups associations or other entities is limited to presenting testimony and information party to the appeal appeals that are a closed record hearing must be upon the record provided that new evidence which was not available at the time of the hearing may be presented in such appeal the term new evidence means evidence discovered after the hearing and shall not include evidence which was available or which could reasonably have been available an appeal must be submitted in writing with the appropriate fee to the city clerk as set forth in chapter  such written appeal shall state specific errors of law fact procedure omissions from the record and errors in the interpretation of the comprehensive plan or new evidence which was not available at the time of the hearing after a timely appeal has been filed and upon payment of fees a hearing will be held by the hearing examiner in accordance with adopted appeal procedures further process is set forth in chapter   1222019   10282014   9272011 editors note  adopted oct 28 201 amended   and in so doing changed the title of said section from appeals to type of hearing and appeal procedure as set out herein   removal an examiner may be removed from office for cause by the affirmative vote of a majority of the city council part 2005   stay during the pendency of an appeal before the hearing examiner or city council the applicant shall stay any grading construction or alteration of the property until final decision of the city council  10282014   9272011   conflict of interest the hearing examiner shall not conduct nor participate in any hearing where the hearing examiner has a direct or indirect personal interest which would influence the decision making process any actual or potential conflict of interest shall be disclosed to the parties immediately upon discovery thereafter either party may object to the hearing examiner continuing in the matter whereupon the hearing examiner shall make a determination as to whether the examiner will continue to preside over the matter  10282014   9272011 chapter 262  labor contract with state   city entrance the city shall enter into that certain collective bargaining agreement entitled working agreement dated  between the city a municipal corporation of the state of washington as employer and the washington state council of county and city employees and local 1135c of the american federation of state county and municipal employees aflcio as the union a copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk  5261970   executiondelivery to union the mayor and city clerk are authorized and directed to execute and deliver to said union the working agreement on behalf of the city  5261970 chapter 266  temporary appointment to classified positions in the police and fire departments   circumstance whenever any member of the classified service in either the police department or in the fire department shall by reason of sickness or injury become physically or mentally unfit for duty the mayor may temporarily appoint another person to perform the duties of such disabled member such other person temporarily appointed shall assume the rank and perform the duties and bear the responsibilities of the classified position to which he is temporarily appointed and shall receive the salary and other compensation provided by law for the position to which he is temporarily appointed  1971   conditions the existence or occurrence of any one of the following events shall be conclusive that a temporary appointment as provided above may be made a the granting of a disability leave to a member of the classified service by the spokane county disability board acting in accordance with rcw   or b the absence from duty of a member of the classified service as a result of sickness or injury for a period of 15 consecutive calendar days where a duly licensed physician has certified that such member cannot reasonably be expected to return to full duty within 180 days from the last day of duty of such member  1971   duration any such temporary appointment shall be for a period of not to exceed six months duration  1971   compliance any such temporary appointment shall be made in accordance with rcw 4108 4112 and the civil service rules of the cheney civil service commission adopted by it pursuant to said chapters  1971   absence report whenever any member of the classified service in either the police department or in the fire department has been absent from duty by reason of injury or illness for 15 or more consecutive calendar days such member shall at the written request of the mayor submit to physical examination by a duly licensed physician designated by the mayor and the designated physician shall determine and report to the mayor the nature and extent of the members illness or injury and the reasonably probable date the member will be able to return to duty as an alternative the mayor may accept the certificate of one of the members attending physicians  1971 chapter 270  code of ethics for public officials and employees   policy declaration high moral and ethical standards among public officials and public employees are essential to gain and maintain the confidence of the public because such confidence is essential to the conduct of free government they are agents of the people and hold their positions for the benefit of the people the proper operation of democratic government requires of public officials and public employees that they be independent and impartial when establishing policy and that their positions never be used for personal gain a code of ethical conduct is necessary for the guidance of public officials and public employees where conflicts do occur as well as to prevent conflicts of interest  1972   definitions public official and public employee include all elected and appointed officers of the city all employees of the city and the members of all city boards and commissions whether compensated by wage or salary or not  1972   use of public property no public official or public employee shall use or permit the use of cityowned vehicles equipment materials or property for personal convenience or profit except when such services are available to the public generally or are provided as city policy for the use of such public official or public employee in the conduct of official business part 1972   obligations to citizen no public official or public employee shall grant nor shall any citizen attempt to obtain any special consideration treatment or advantage beyond that which is available to every other citizen part 1972   ethics the purpose of the code of ethics is to assist public officials and public employees to establish guidelines to govern their own conduct the code is also intended to help develop traditions of responsible public service no public official or public employee shall engage in any act which is in conflict with the performance of his official duties a public official or public employee shall be deemed to have a conflict of interest if he 1 receives or has any financial interest in any sale to or by the city of any service or property when such financial interest was received with the prior knowledge that the city intended to purchase such property or obtain such service  2 accepts or seeks for others any service information or thing of value on more favorable terms than those granted to the public generally from any person firm or corporation having dealings with the city  3 accepts any gift or favor from any person firm or corporation having any dealings with the city if he knows or has reason to know that it was intended to obtain special consideration  4 influences the selection of or the conduct of business with a corporation person or firm having business with the city if he personally or relatives has financial interest in or with the corporation person or firm  provided however that this section shall not apply to any transaction specifically authorized by rcw   5 is an employee officer partner director or consultant of any corporation firm or person having business with the city unless he has disclosed such relationship as provided by subsection 9 of this section  6 engages in or accepts private employment or renders services for private industry when such employment or service is incompatible with the proper discharge of his official duties or would impair his independence of judgment or action in the performance of his official duties  7 appears in behalf of a private interest before any regulatory governmental agency or represents a private interest in any action or proceeding against the interest of the city in any litigation to which the city is a party unless he has a personal interest and this personal interest has been disclosed to the regulatory governmental agency a councilman may appear before regulatory governmental agencies on behalf of constituents in the course of his duties as a representative of the electorate or in the performance of public or civic obligations  however no public official or public employee shall accept a retainer or compensation that is contingent upon a specific action by a city agency  8 directly or indirectly possesses a substantial or controlling interest in any business entity which conducts business or contracts with the city or in the sale of real estate materials supplies or services to the city without disclosing such interest as provided by subsection 9 of this section an interest is not a substantial interest if such interest does not exceed onetenth of one percent of the outstanding securities of the business concern  or if the interest is an unincorporated business concern one percent of the net worth of such concern  or the financial interest of a corporation person or firm does not exceed five percent of the net worth of the public employee and his household relatives  9 as a councilman has a financial or other private interest in any legislation or other matters coming before the council and fails to disclose such an interest on the records of the city council this provision shall not apply if the councilman disqualifies himself from voting by stating the nature and extent of such interest any other public official or public employee who has a financial or other private interest and who participates in discussion with or gives an official opinion to the council and fails to disclose on the records of the council the nature and extent of such interest is in violation of this chapter  1972   violationpenalty a any person who knowingly and intentionally violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor b any person firm corporation or organization which willfully attempts to secure preferential treatment in its dealings with the city by offering any valuable gifts whether in the form of services loan thing or promise or any other form to any public official or public employee shall have its current contracts with the city cancelled and shall not be able to bid on any other city contract for a period of two years  1972 chapter 271  appearance of fairness   challenge of decisionprocedure a washington state law requires that all hearings which are quasijudicial in nature shall comply with the appearance of fairness doctrine and decision makers require reasonable advance notice in order to be able to respond any person who wishes to challenge any decision maker on the grounds of the appearance of fairness shall file a written statement on a form provided by the city clerk not later than  pm on the last working day prior to the day of the hearing b any person who fails to timely file the written statement as required by the ordinance codified in this chapter shall be deemed to have waived any objection on the grounds of appearance of fairness  2000 chapter 272  procedures for authorizing the defense of claims or actions against an elected or appointed officer employee or volunteer   purpose a the ordinance codified in this chapter implements the requirements of rcw  as hereafter amended requiring local governmental agencies to create a procedure for authorizing the defense of an action or proceeding brought against an elected or appointed officer employee or volunteer at the expense of the city b this chapter also authorizes the indemnification of an officer employee or volunteer of the city in accordance with rcw  and chapter 4862 rcw as hereafter amended  2000   standard of conduct this chapter applies to any threatened or pending action claim or other proceeding against any past or present elected or appointed officer employee or volunteer of the city to the extent the conduct arises out of and is within the scope of such person in good faith performance purported performance or failure of performance of his or her official duties  2000   determination of conduct unless ordered or adjudged by a court of competent jurisdiction the defense and indemnification of an elected or appointed officer employee or volunteer may be authorized only as follows 1 to the extent that the claimant has been successful on the merits  and 2 where there has been a determination by a majority vote of all the city council not interested in or a party to the action claim or other proceeding that the standard of conduct requirement in section  has been satisfied in the event a majority vote cannot be obtained because of the interest of members of the city council then all members of the city council shall be permitted to vote  2000   notice any past or present elected or appointed officer employee or volunteer who seeks defense and indemnification in any action claim or proceeding must give notice in writing to the mayor of his or her request for defense and indemnification before incurring any costs disbursements or attorneys fees for which reimbursement is sought and provide a copy of any and all claims pleadings reports or other written statements regarding the allegations  2000   scope of defense and indemnification a general the city shall pay the reasonable and necessary expenses actually incurred and connected with the defense settlement or monetary judgments including costs disbursements and reasonable attorneys fees arising out of any action claim or other proceeding within the standard of conduct referred to in section  and for which notice has been given pursuant to section  the city council shall be the sole judge of the reasonable and necessary expenses to be borne by the city b punitive damages the city council may authorize payment of an award of punitive damages by a majority vote of the full council c criminal conduct defense and indemnification shall not be authorized for any claim or action founded upon a violation of a statute law rule or regulation punishable by fine imprisonment or both  2000 chapter 274  disposal of surplus property footnotes  13  editors note  adopted  effective  repealed the former ch 274   of said ordinance enacted a new ch 274 as set out herein the former ch 274 pertained to city property sale and derived from  adopted 1974  part adopted 1987   adopted 1997   surplus city property whenever it appears to the mayor that any real or personal property owned by the city no longer has utility to the city and it would be in the best interest of the city to sell and dispose of the property the mayor is authorized to dispose of the real or personal property as follows 1 if the reasonable value for a parcel or portion thereof of real property or an item of personal property has greater value than $500000 the mayor shall refer the matter to the city council for consideration and action 2 for real and personal property having a value of less than $500000 the mayor may declare the same as surplus and sell or dispose of the property as set forth in this chapter  7242012   sale of surplus property disposing of property real property or personal property with a value less than $500000 surplus property which no longer has utility to the city may be disposed of at public or private sale with the proceeds from such sale paid into the fund from which such property was acquired surplus property will be offered for sale transfer or donation of the following methods a sale or transfer to other governmental entity  b sale to the general public by auction sealed bid or negotiation  or c donation to an organization that supports the poor or the infirm upon agreement to use the property for such purposes 1 disposal priorities a surplus property will be transferred or sold for reasonable value if practical b surplus property that does not have a reasonable market value with the cost of sale or disposition exceeding its value may at the discretion of the mayor be disposed of in the most efficient and expeditious manner 2 valuation the minimum price to be obtained for the sale of surplus property shall be established by the mayor a an appraisal of the property by a person knowledgeable or experienced in valuing such property  b review of similar property offered for sale acceptable commercial transactions such as publicprivate offers found in a newspaper trade publication internet site or other reasonable source  or c through an exercise of reasonable judgment based upon an opinion of value from persons familiar with the property real property with an estimated value in excess of $500000 shall have the minimum price set based upon the opinion of an individual either licensed to sell and offer real estate or certified to perform written appraisals in the state of washington 3 utility property whenever real or personal property has been acquired for public utility purposes which no longer has utility to the needs of the city a public hearing shall be held before the city council before the property may be lease sold or conveyed rcw  at the public hearing the city council shall consider a resolution that identifies the surplus property  provided that for items of personal property with an estimated value of less than $500000 per item the resolution may state miscellaneous items of personal property not exceeding $500000 per item are set forth on an attached exhibit the resolution may also identify certain utility property that will be disposed of recycling or other specialized company such as transformers wires and other facilities where it is in the public interest to dispose of these items according to good utility practices 4 methods of disposal a public auction the city may dispose of surplus property to the general public conducted by the city its agent or any local governmental entity b sealed bid the city may dispose of surplus property bid provided the city places public notice in a newspaper of general circulation and on the city website bids shall be opened and announced to the public at the time and place stated in the offer requesting bids the city shall accept the highest bid for the property provided such bid is equal to or greater than the established minimum price nothing herein prevents the mayor or city council from rejecting all bids a bid request is an invitation to make an offer to purchase property acceptance occurs of consideration or other written acknowledgment by the city c negotiation sale shall be done at armslength which means there is a willing seller and a willing buyer with neither party obligated to buy or sell the property a good faith attempt shall be made by the mayor or designee to obtain a reasonable price that reflects the market value of the property d notice the notice of the surplus property shall include a description of the item the date for the public bid opening and a statement that further information may be obtained office of the city clerk the date of notice on the city website and in the newspaper shall be at least ten days prior to the bid opening when a public hearing is required the notice of the public hearing shall be set forth on the city council agenda and be posted on the citys website notice and publication in newspaper of general circulation shall not be necessary when the sale is to another governmental entity or the city determines that the property will be donated to an organization that supports the poor or the infirm  6232015   7242012   negotiation negotiation shall be the method of disposal whenever the mayor determines that such procedure is the most advantageous to the city the reasons for selecting disposition by negotiation shall be set forth in the records of the city  7242012   warranty guarantee of quality and conveyance all sales of surplus property shall be as is and the city takes no responsibility for and makes no guarantee with respect to the sold items to the extent known the city shall disclose significant defects prior to sale no sale shall be invalid due to a defect discovered after sale which may have been discovered by reasonable inspection of the property this condition of sale is automatically incorporated into all transactions between the city and the purchasers of surplus property the mayor and city clerk are authorized to execute such documents as are necessary to convey the property to the purchaser in the event it is necessary to convey real property the deed shall be presented to city council for final approval no conveyance shall occur until payment of the full purchase price  7242012   withdrawal from sale or rejection of bids the city may withdraw from sale any item at any time prior to the formation of a contract to include rejecting any and all bids to serve the best interest of the city  7242012   sale of surplus property to appointed officials or employees surplus property shall not be sold to appointed officials or employees of the city except an item of a personal nature that was exclusively used during employment which depicts or represents their office or service may be sold to such person upon termination of employment as surplus property for reasonable value city officials who are involved in the decision to surplus city property or administer the sale are prohibited from purchasing surplus property from the city upon retirement or special recognition of a city employee the city may declare certain items of personal property to have no continuing value to the city and present such items to the individual as a recognition of exemplary service to the city  7242012   notification to accounting a detailed list including description asset tag number former location responsible department and sales price for all items disposed shall be sent to the city finance director immediately after disposal for removal from the capital asset management system  7242012 chapter 278  information gathering and analyzing   findingspurpose it is determined by the city council that the study and collection of information data and opinions on the administrative and enforcement efficiency and costs attendant therewith and the societal effects of proposed pending or enacted legislation is necessary for legislative planning or revision and that a prompt informative response to inquiries from legislators and public administrators and attendance at legislative committee hearings relating to the effect of legislation on municipal finances services and authority is necessary and helpful to the legislator in the enlightened performance of the legislative function and serves the best interests of the citizens and the public and is declared to be a municipal purpose  1976   mayor to designate persons to gather and analyze information the mayor is authorized to designate city employees or representatives to collect accumulate and analyze information concerning the effect of enacted legislation or the anticipated effect of proposed or pending legislation  to consult with employees or representatives of other municipalities or counties and associations thereof  to respond and provide data and information and give testimony to state legislators legislative committees state administrative officers or other municipalities investigating the citys experience or anticipated costs benefits or problems from such enacted or proposed legislation  1976   citys representativeduties generally in all matters in which an official staff employee or other representative appears on behalf of the city such representative shall observe carry out or support the known relevant policies of the city council and shall consult the mayor andor the city council for advice and guidance when required all such informational activity shall be conducted with prudence and good judgment and within all legal regulation of such activity such representative shall not have any authority to make any statements commitments or promises binding upon the city but may speak to influence the passage defeat or amendment of legislation affecting the city in accordance with the policy or position approved by the city council  1976   citys representativecompensation while engaged in such informational educational and testimonial activity a city employee shall continue to receive his or her current salary as a city employee no additional compensation shall be paid or accrue to an elected official during his or her term of office with the city for such research informational or lobbying services to this city an employee or official shall receive reimbursement for the reasonable costs of travel lodging and personal meals reasonably incurred in the course of such service in accordance with the citys regular policies and rates as to such reimbursement  1976   entertainment expenditures nonreimbursable no expenditures from city funds for the hosting entertainment or campaign assistance of any legislator or state officer shall be authorized expended or reimbursed  1976   lobbying activities to comply with state regulations the citys employee or representative in such informational or lobbying activities shall comply fully with all state regulations relating to ethical practices and conduct and comply with all regulations relating to the reporting of expenditures in connection therewith  1976 chapter 280  small contract authority   purpose the mayor has the responsibility to supervise the administration of the city government and its interests to include ensuring that all contracts and agreements are faithfully kept and performed for the benefit of the city to facilitate the efficient administration of the city when procuring goods services equipment property and public works the city council grants the mayor purchasing and contract authority in amounts and conditions set forth in this chapter  682010   purchase authority the mayor may enter into contracts to include amendments and establish a binding commitment between the city and a person or entity for the purpose of procuring goods services equipment property and public works which are routine and necessary acquisitions in the best interest of the city the authority of the mayor is conditioned upon the following 1 the procurement has been authorized appropriation of the city council  2 the contract and amount is reported to the city council at the next regularly scheduled city council meeting  and 3 the total amount of the contract or amendment does not exceed $1000000 the above contracts are effective without specific approval by the city council provided the mayor may elect to present any contract to the city council for consideration  682010   contract change orders and contract amendments the mayor pursuant to policy adopted by the city council may authorize changes in work change order or contract amendment provided such funds have been previously appropriated or otherwise made available by the city council  682010   contract procurement the mayor is authorized to adopt rules and regulations for the procurement of goods services equipment property and public works to include but not be limited to development of bid specifications bid requests notice and award provided the same are consistent with state law and city ordinance it is the intent of the council to promote fair and competitive bid practices for the city all adopted rules policies and procedures shall be filed with the city clerk and available for public inspection  682010 chapter 286  creation administration and financing of local improvement districts   duties of various city officials unless otherwise ordered by the mayor or prescribed by law the following city officials will perform the duties indicated with respect to the creation administration and financing of all local improvement districts of the city 1 city clerk the city clerk is responsible for receiving all petitions for the creation of local improvement districts giving all required public notices and placing all matters upon the agenda for council consideration 2 city engineer the city engineer shall prepare all assessment rolls and preliminary assessment rolls determine the sufficiency of all petitions for the creation of local improvement districts and be in charge of the physical construction of the public works authorized by this chapter 3 city treasurer the city treasurer shall perform all the duties required of the treasurer in rcw chapters 3543 inclusive  negotiate obtain and administer all short term financing and otherwise administer all the financing provisions of local improvement districts including but not limited to the maintenance and administration of assessment rolls the guarantee fund bonds and warrants and property acquired by foreclosure and superintend foreclosure of all delinquent assessments 4 mayor the mayor shall have overall responsibility for local improvements by the city and in all cases not specifically covered by law ordinance or resolution determine the proper means of administering such local improvements  1984   delinquent installmentspenalties whenever any annual or other installment upon any local improvement assessment shall become delinquent there shall immediately be added to such delinquent installment a sum equal to such portion of the delinquent sum as is determined by multiplying the delinquent sum by the rate of interest applicable to the assessment increased by five percentage points the sum so determined shall thereafter accrue interest at the same rate as the balance of the assessment a new penalty shall be assessed each year and shall include a penalty upon all prior penalties assessed and not paid  1984 chapter 290  hotelmotel tax advisory committee   hotelmotel tax advisory committee a hotelmotel tax advisory committee is established the purpose of the hotelmotel tax advisory committee is to perform the functions of a lodging tax advisory committee under rcw  with duties as described in this chapter or as directed by the city council following procedures as provided in this chapter  2007   membership and term the hotelmotel tax advisory committee shall be comprised of five voting members each appointed by the cheney city council the cheney city council may appoint nonvoting members to the htac members of the htac are not required to be residents of the city of cheney with the exception of the elected official required by state law 1 voting members shall be as follows a one member shall be either the mayor or a cheney city council member who shall serve as chair  b two members shall be representatives of businesses required to collect tax under this chapter  c two members shall be persons involved in activities authorized to be funded by revenue received under this chapter 2 the term of membership shall be of the year following appointment  provided that a members term shall not expire until the appointment of a new member is effective by statute eligibility for appointment under subsection 1b or 1c of this section is mutually exclusive the city council shall review the membership of the advisory committee annually and make changes as appropriate each year organizations representing businesses required to collect the lodging tax organizations involved in activities authorized to be funded by lodging tax revenue and local agencies involved in tourism promotion may submit recommendations for membership on the htac  2007   duties a a city proposal shall be submitted to the hotelmotel tax advisory committee for review and comment if the city proposes an increase in the rate of the tax imposed under this chapter the repeal of an exemption from a tax imposed under this chapter or a change in the use of revenue received under this chapter the hotelmotel tax advisory committee shall submit comments on such a proposal to the city council in a timely manner applicable public comment procedures comments from the hotelmotel tax advisory committee shall include an analysis of the extent to which the proposal will accommodate activities for tourists or increase tourism and the extent to which the proposal will affect the longterm stability of the lodging tax fund created under this chapter b the hotelmotel tax advisory committee should submit its comments on the proposal no more than 44 days after its receipt of the proposal however failure of the hotelmotel tax advisory committee to submit comments shall not prevent the city from acting on the proposal once 45 days have elapsed since the proposal was submitted to the hotelmotel tax advisory committee the city is not required to submit an amended proposal to the hotelmotel tax advisory committee c in addition to the foregoing the hotelmotel tax advisory committee will submit a report to the citys finance director as to whether the proposed budget for hotelmotel tax revenue and hotelmotel fund expenditures is consistent with longterm stability of the lodging tax fund  2007   quorum a quorum of the hotelmotel tax advisory committee shall be a majority of persons currently serving as voting members of the committee a quorum must be present in order for a vote to be taken on a recommendation to go to the city council  2007   procedure a the chair shall propose an agenda for meetings shall preside at all meetings and shall vote on matters being voted on by hotelmotel tax advisory committee meeting the chair shall be responsible for assuring that hotelmotel tax advisory committee meeting reports are presented to the city on time and shall select a member to record decisions of hotelmotel tax advisory committee meeting that establish policies or recommendations b the hotelmotel tax advisory committee meeting may select a vicechair or a temporary chair to act in the absence of the chair c the hotelmotel tax advisory committee meeting may adopt a written policy of hotelmotel tax advisory committee meeting practices not inconsistent with this chapter or other direction of city council  2007   voting each voting member as defined in this chapter is entitled to one vote all matters establishing policies recommendations or decisions shall be decided by a majority vote of voting members present  2007   compensation and reimbursement of expenses the members of the hotelmotel tax advisory committee meeting shall receive no compensation however the hotelmotel tax advisory committee may request specific support andor expenses necessary to carry out its responsibilities by a request made in advance to the mayor and approved by city council  2007   removal a member of hotelmotel tax advisory committee meeting may be removed during the members term by the city council only for sufficient cause sufficient cause means 1 absence for two consecutive meetings without prior excuse from the chair  or 2 a violation of the public trust or malfeasance in the judgment of the city council whose decision shall be final and nonappealable  2007   annual economic impact report the hotelmotel tax advisory committee shall assist the city in compiling an annual economic impact report and such other reports to the department of community trade and economic development required by law including but not limited to section  of the revised washington  2007 title 3  finance chapter 304  warrants footnotes  1  order of redemption prescribed by statutesee rcw 35a   order of redemption all city warrants of immediate repairs to facilities caused by storm flood or other unforeseen casualty cause  effective 111957   garbage equipment reserve fund  created  purpose under provisions of chapter 60 laws of and appurtenances for park and recreation purposes for the construction of structures buildings or other improvements on property devoted to park and recreation purposes for the acquisition and created hereby and the fund paid therein as required hereinbefore shall be used solely for the purpose of the payment of the principal of the bonds authorized hereby as they mature and become payable and for the payment of the interest thereon as the same accrues and becomes payable as provided in the interest coupons which shall be attached to the bonds without preference or priority of the interest upon one bond over another bond maturing in any year by reason of its numbering priority of issuance or otherwise part 8151960   contributions in aid of construction fundcreated there is imposed a sales or use tax as the case may be as authorized by rcw 2 upon every taxable event as defined in rcw  occurring within the city of cheney the tax shall be imposed upon and collected from those persons from whom the state sales tax or use tax is collected pursuant to rcw chapters 8208 and 8212  1983   rate the rate of the tax imposed by section  shall be onehalf of one percent of the selling price or value of the article used as the case may be  provided however that during such period as there is in effect a sales tax or use tax imposed by spokane county under section 172 chapter 49 laws of 198 first extraordinary session at a rate equal to or greater than the rate imposed by this section the county shall receive 15 percent of the tax imposed by section   provided further that during such period as there is in effect a sales tax or use tax imposed by spokane county under section 172 chapter 49 laws of 198 first extraordinary session at a rate which is less than the rate imposed by this section the county shall receive from the tax imposed by section  that amount of revenues equal to 15 percent of the rate of the tax imposed by the county under section 172 chapter 49 laws of 198 first extraordinary session  1983   administration and collection the administration and collection of the tax imposed by this chapter shall be in accordance with the provisions of rcw   1983   inspection of records the city of cheney consents to the inspection of such records as are necessary to qualify the city for inspection of records of the department of revenue pursuant to rcw   1983   entrance into contract the mayor and clerk are authorized to enter into a contract with the department of revenue for the administration of this tax  1983   referendum procedure this chapter shall be subject to referendum as provided in chapter 99 laws of washington 1983 regular session  1983   penalties any seller who fails or refuses to collect the tax as required with the intent to violate the provisions of this chapter or to gain some advantage or benefit either direct or indirect and any buyer who refuses to pay any tax due under this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined no more than $50000 or imprisoned for not more than six months or by both such fine and imprisonment  1983 chapter 316  travel expenses   applicability whenever city officials or employees are authorized to travel outside the city of cheney or its immediate environs on official city business for the purpose of conducting city business or for the purpose of attending meetings conferences or conventions on behalf of the city the manner and amount of reimbursement for the expense incurred shall be as set out in this chapter  1973   basis for reimbursementsubsistence and lodging expenses a the reimbursement for subsistence and lodging expenses incurred on official business shall be on an actual expense basis whereby the employee or official will be reimbursed by the city for the reasonable and justifiable expense incurred during official travel b reimbursement shall be allowed only where the number of travel hours of an employee before andor after the employees regularly scheduled working hours of any one day total three or more except that the actual cost of luncheon or dinner meals away from the city may be made without regard to the travel hours where it is necessary for the employee to incur the cost of a meal with one or more individuals with whom his business is being conducted in such cases the actual reasonable cost of the employees own meal may be reimbursed  1973   reimbursementperiod over 14 daysoptions in lieu of the reimbursement of city officials and employees for subsistence expenses incurred on official business on an actual expense basis as provided in section  of the cheney city when travel is performed by a city official or employee on official business over a period of 14 consecutive days and upon approval of the mayor the city official or employee performing such travel may elect to receive the sum of $2000 per day for subsistence part 1988   1975   reimbursable transportation expenses reimbursable transportation expenses include all necessary official travel on railroads airlines ships buses private automobiles and other usual means of conveyance  1973   reimbursement for use of privately owned automobile a reimbursement shall be allowed at a rate per mile to be determined by the finance committee for official travel mileage between points in the state shall be determined on the basis of the distances shown on the latest state highway commission map and the outofstate mileage on the basis of standard highway mileage guides or by speedometer readings vicinity miles as determined by speedometer readings shall be shown on the vouchers as a separate figure for each days travel b reimbursement shall be payable to only one of two or more employees traveling on the same trip in the same automobile  1991   1984   1979   1973   miscellaneous travel expenses a miscellaneous travel expenses essential to the transaction of official city business are reimbursable to the employee reimbursable expenses include but are not limited to 1 taxi fares car rentals parking fees and ferry and bridge tolls  2 registration fees required in connection with attendance at conventions conferences and official meetings  3 rental of rooms in a hotel or other place which is used to transact official business the room rental is reimbursable as a separate item when authorized  4 tips and gratuities up to but not exceeding 15 percent b certain travel expenses are considered as personal and not essential to the transaction of official city businesses such nonreimbursable expenses include but are not limited to 1 laundry valet service and entertainment expenses radio or television rental and other items of a similar nature  2 taxi fares car rental and other transportation costs to places of entertainment and other similar facilities  3 costs of personal trip insurance and medical and hospital services  4 person telephone calls to the home of an employee except where a brief call is made to advise the employees family of a change in travel plans part 1988   1973   credit card authorization employees and officers shall be issued a credit card in lieu of advance travel with preauthorization of the mayor to be used for travel expenses except for reimbursable transportation expenses on railroad airlines ships buses private automobiles and other usual means of conveyance and registration fees required in connection with travel in accordance with section 2  1988   voucher and receipts employees and officers shall claim reimbursement for travel on form of voucher to be furnished by the clerk receipt or other proof of expenditure for any single item of $1000 or more must be furnished with the voucher  1973   control of travel a reimbursable official travel may be authorized by the following for all overnight travel and all travel over 100 road miles from the limits of the city the mayor  for all other travel the department head of the employee performing the travel b in any case the city council may authorize reimbursable official travel  1973 chapter 320  real estate tax   imposition there is imposed a tax of onequarter of one percent of the selling price on each sale of real property within the corporate limits of this city  1982   taxable events taxes imposed herein shall be collected from persons who are taxable by the state under chapter 8245 rcw and chapter 45861 wac upon the occurrence of any taxable event within the corporate limits of the city  1982   consistency with state tax the taxes imposed herein shall comply with all applicable rules regulations laws and court decisions regarding real estate excise taxes as imposed by the state under chapter 8245 rcw and chapter 45861 wac the provisions of those chapters to the extent they are not inconsistent with this ordinance shall apply as though fully set forth herein  1952   distribution of tax proceeds and limiting the use thereof 1 the county treasurer shall place one percent of the proceeds of the taxes imposed herein in the county current expense fund to defray costs of collection 2 the remaining proceeds from city taxes imposed herein shall be distributed to the city monthly and those taxes imposed under section  shall be placed by the city treasurer in a municipal capital improvements fund which fund is established as a separate fund these capital improvements funds shall be used by the city for local improvements including those listed in rcw  3 this section shall not limit the existing authority of this city to impose special assessments on property benefited thereby in the manner prescribed by law  1982   sellers obligation the taxes imposed herein are the obligation of the seller and may be enforced action of debt against the seller or in the manner prescribed for the foreclosure of mortgages  1982   lien provisions the taxes imposed herein and any interest or penalties thereon are the specific lien upon each piece of real property sold from the time of sale or until the tax is paid which lien may be enforced in the manner prescribed for the foreclosure of mortgages resort to one course of enforcement is not an election not to pursue the other  1982   notation of payment the taxes imposed herein shall be paid to and collected by the treasurer of spokane county the spokane county treasurer shall act as agent for the city the county treasurer shall cause a stamp evidencing satisfaction of the lien to be affixed to the instrument of sale or conveyance prior to its recording or to the real estate tax affidavit in the case of used mobile home sales a receipt issued by the county treasurer for the payment of the tax imposed herein shall be evidence of the satisfaction of the lien imposed in section  and may be recorded in the manner prescribed for recording satisfactions or mortgages no instrument of sale or conveyance evidencing a sale subject to the tax may be accepted by the county auditor for filing or recording until the tax is paid and the stamp affixed thereto in case the tax is not due on the transfer the instrument shall not be accepted until suitable notation of this fact is made on the instrument by the county treasurer  1982   date payable the tax imposed hereunder shall become due and payable immediately at the time of sale and if not so paid within 30 days thereafter shall bear interest at the rate of one percent per month from the time of sale until the date of payment  1982   excessive and improper payments if upon written application by a taxpayer to the county treasurer for a refund it appears a tax has been paid in excess of the amount actually due or upon a sale or other transfer declared to be exempt such excess amount or improper payment shall be refunded by the county treasurer to the taxpayer  provided that no refund shall be made unless the state has first authorized the refund of an excessive amount or an improper amount paid unless such improper amount was paid as a result of a miscalculation any refund made shall be withheld from the next monthly distribution to the city  1982 chapter 324  leasehold excise tax   levied there is levied and shall be collected a leasehold excise tax on and after  upon the act or privilege of occupying or using publicly owned real or personal property within the city of cheney leasehold interest as defined in chapter 61 laws of washington of 197576 second extraordinary session hereinafter the state act and incorporated in this chapter by reference the tax shall be paid collected and remitted to the department of revenue state of washington  1977   collectionremitted to state department of revenue the tax shall be paid collected and remitted to the department of revenue state of washington at the time and in the manner prescribed by section 5 of the state act  1977   collectionadministration administration and collection of the tax imposed by this chapter shall be in accordance with the provisions of this state act  1977   rate the rate of the tax imposed shall be four percent of the taxable rent as defined by section 2 of the state act  1977   credits the following credits shall be allowed in determining the tax payable 1 with respect to a leasehold interest arising out of any lease or agreement the terms of which were binding and the lessee prior to  where such lease or agreement has not been renegotiated as defined by section 2 of the state act since that date and excluding from such credit any lease or agreement including options to renew which extends beyond  as follows a with respect to taxes due in the calendar year 197 a credit equal to 60 percent of the tax produced by the rate designated in this chapter b with respect to taxes due in the calendar year 197 a credit equal to 40 percent of the tax produced by the rate designated in this chapter c with respect to taxes due in the calendar year 197 a credit equal to 20 percent of the tax produced by the rate designated in this chapter  2 with respect to a product lease as defined by section 2 of the state act a credit of 33 percent of the tax produced by the rate designated in this chapter  1977   exemption leasehold interests exempted by section 13 of the state act as it now exists or may hereafter be amended shall be exempt from the tax imposed pursuant to section
